de.esoco.data.element

Class StringDataElement

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.property.AbstractStringProperties
      • de.esoco.lib.property.StringProperties
        • de.esoco.data.element.DataElement<java.lang.String>
          • de.esoco.data.element.StringDataElement
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    de.esoco.lib.property.HasProperties, de.esoco.lib.property.MutableProperties, java.io.Serializable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ProcessDescription, SelectionDataElement

    public class StringDataElement
extends DataElement<java.lang.String>
    A data element implementation that contains a string value.
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • StringDataElement

        public StringDataElement(java.lang.String sName,
                         java.lang.String sValue,
                         Validator<? super java.lang.String> rValidator,
                         java.util.Set<DataElement.Flag> rFlags)
        Creates a new instance with a constraint for the possible element values. The constraint is defined in form of a regular expression pattern against which new element values will be matched.
        Parameters:
        sName - The name of this element
        sValue - The value of this element
        rValidator - The validator for the value or NULL for none
        rFlags - The optional flags for this data element

    • Method Detail

      • getPhoneNumberParts

        public static java.util.List<java.lang.String> getPhoneNumberParts(java.lang.String sNumber)
        Splits a phone number string into it's distinct parts and returns a list containing the parts. The list will contain 4 elements: Country code, area code, phone number, and extension. Empty parts will be returned as empty strings but will never be NULL.
        Parameters:
        sNumber - The phone number string
        Returns:
        A list containing the 4 number parts

      • copy

        public StringDataElement copy(DataElement.CopyMode eMode,
                              de.esoco.lib.property.PropertyName<?>... rCopyProperties)
        Returns a copy of this data element that contains all or a subset of it's current state. Always copied are the name and flags. Never copied is the parent reference because upon copying typically a reference to a copied parent needs to be set. The further data the copy contains depends on the copy mode:
        • DataElement.CopyMode.FULL: The copy contains all data (except the parent reference).
        • DataElement.CopyMode.FLAT: like DataElement.CopyMode.FULL but without sub-ordinate data elements.
        • DataElement.CopyMode.PROPERTIES: The copy contains only the properties but not the element value and attributes.
        • DataElement.CopyMode.PLACEHOLDER: The copy contains only the element name to serve as a placeholder.

        The copy instance is created by invoking DataElement.newInstance() which has the recommendation to overwrite the return type to the concrete subtype to prevent the need for casting by the invoking code. For the same reason it is recommended that subclasses also override this method with the concrete return type and cast the result of super.copy() to that type.

        Overrides:
        copy in class DataElement<java.lang.String>
        Parameters:
        eMode - The copy mode
        rCopyProperties - An optional list of properties to copy. If not provided all properties will be copied (unless the mode is DataElement.CopyMode.PLACEHOLDER)
        Returns:
        The copied instance

      • getValue

        public final java.lang.String getValue()
        //~ Methods ---------------------------------------------------------------- /*************************************** Returns the value of this element. Each subclass must implement this method separately because some environments (like GWT) require serializable objects to use specific types for serializable fields. Therefore it is not possible to store a generic Object value in the base class.
        Specified by:
        getValue in class DataElement<java.lang.String>
        Returns:
        The element value

      • isValidValue

        public boolean isValidValue(java.lang.String rValue)
        Overridden to allow any value if this instance has the user interface property LIST_STYLE with a value of EDITABLE.
        Overrides:
        isValidValue in class DataElement<java.lang.String>
        Parameters:
        rValue - The value to check
        Returns:
        TRUE if the value is valid for this data element
        See Also:
        DataElement.isValidValue(Object)

      • setStringValue

        public void setStringValue(java.lang.String sValue)
        Sets a string value. This method must be overridden by subclasses that want to support the setting of string values in parallel to their native datatype. The default implementation always throws a runtime exception.
        Overrides:
        setStringValue in class DataElement<java.lang.String>
        Parameters:
        sValue - The new string value

      • newInstance

        protected StringDataElement newInstance()
        Returns a new instance of the respective data element sub-type on which it is invoked. This is needed for GWT which doesn't support reflection. Used by DataElement.copy(CopyMode, PropertyName...) for cloning an instance. Implementations should overwrite the return type with their concrete type to prevent the need for casting by the invoking code.
        Specified by:
        newInstance in class DataElement<java.lang.String>
        Returns:
        The new instance

      • updateValue

        protected final void updateValue(java.lang.String sNewValue)
        Updates the element value. Will be invoked by DataElement.setValue(Object) to store a new value after validation. If a subclass wants to reject certain values it should do so in the DataElement.isValidValue(Object) method. Subclasses that are always immutable should implement an assertion because if the element has been initialized correctly (validator = NULL) this method should then be reached.
        Specified by:
        updateValue in class DataElement<java.lang.String>
        Parameters:
        sNewValue - The new value for this element
